author: Incartades

description.text: This is the first ever physical Clout Coin! Get some Clout.

Need a small tripod for our mini Christmas tree, so I ended up designing a parametric tripod stand for rods.

It can hold either round or square rods (specify diagonal!), can be thin or strong, can have leg pads, open bottom, etc.

Recommend using the pads at the end of the legs for better bed adhesion (hint: set Leg Pads parameter to 0.1, that way you can detach them later if you prefer the clean tripod look).

This is a RUNCAM3-Mount for a 5" 210 Lisam Racequad-Frame. Its angle is 25°.

I have printed this two times and improved this model from time to time now it works perfect for me. The runcam 3 fits perfectly in it. And the Mounting grid should fit most 5" frames as well.

How i designed this: pen&paper measuring -> Fusion360 -> Simplify3D -> Creality3D CR-10

I printed this with Orange Kaisertech PLA (http://amzn.to/2CbxVle).

description.text:
A nice snowflake.

Un bonito copo de nieve

This is a quite handy little tablet stand that has been measured to fit the 8-inch 16:10 nVidia Shield Tablet. It should fit most 8-inch tablets, as well as 6-7 inch, and 9-10 inch tablets, but these sizes have not been tested.

With an 8 inch tablet it holds it at a viewing angle of ~60 degrees relative to the base. I test printed it with PLA on a Da Vinci Jr. 1.0 Pro by XYZPrinting, using 10% infill, and it's rock solid. The tablet has very little sway, it is sturdy enough to type on, and the back seems to be holding strong.

This was designed using Autodesk's Fusion 360 CAD software.

title: Ender 4 Reinforced Z Axis Motor Mount Fixed

description.text: When I printed out the thing this is a remix the holes on the motor were not lining up with the slots. Started investigating and realized issue was in the original design, NEMA 17 motors have 31mm spacing between motor mount holes and original thing had 32mm spacing, hence nothing lined up. Also had issue with almost no tolerance allowance on the mounting holes. I fixed both of those issues and now everything lines up and fits the way it should.

title: Raspberry Pi 7" Laser Cut Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This stand was designed to hold a Raspberry Pi 3 and one of the commonly available HDMI 7" touch screen displays.It was designed to work with 1/8" (Around 3mm) acrylic. M3 0.5 10mm and 20mm screws were used for assembly however other sizes may work.

This part is not designed it be printed it is designed to be laser cut and therefore a dxf file has been provided as the source. I cut it on a K40 laser cutter modified to have GRBL controls.
A 3D model was created in Rhino3D and then that was flattened down to curves to get a dxf file to be used for laser cutting.

description.text:
Bicycle Flashlight Mount

I created a simple bicycle flashlight mount with that required fewer attachments when setting it up. I found that having zip ties and a "Hook and Loop" fastener (Velcro Strap). I found many designs online and I wanted to recreate one for my handlebar.

Check out the Full Story of this Project

3D Printing Blog | Bicycle Lights Ver. 1​

Instructions

Attach the mount on the handlebar with some zip ties or hook and loop fastener as shown in the thumbnails. Then place your flashlight on top of the mount. I recommend the use of low profile flashlights similar to the thumbnails.

Support 3D Creator

If you would like to help me create more cool things and remake stuff, or buy me coffee that would fuel my creativity, you can by clicking here.

Until next time..I bid you adieu....

For more DIY Projects or DIY Stories, visit my website at 3dsolio.com

description.text:
Little flat mount for the Wolfwhoop WT02 camera. Flat mount.
Two ways you can make it work:
1: Print it at 102-103 percent
-or-
2: Print it at 100 percent, carefully JAM IT IN (it's really tight)
then run the camera for about 20 minutes.
The camera gets hot, the plastic softens a bit, and then it fits perfect!

Be careful if you choose the second method as you may ruin the camera by breaking off the delicate surface mount parts.

title: Propeller Blade for Visuo Siluroid XS809 Quadcopter Drone

description.text:
Blew through all of my clockwise propellers and the two spares that came with my Visuo Siluroid XS809 H-W-VGA quadcopter drone within two days of ownership. By the time I'd broken my last spare I already had a mockup put together in OpenSCAD ready to start testing and amazingly enough they worked without a hitch so I'm uploading the SCAD and STL files for anyone else with this drone or similar so you can print spare blades.

I take no responsibility for the long-term effects these blades might have on the performance or durability of your drone, its gears or its motors, use with caution and at your own risk as they come with no warranty and use of them will likely void whatever warranty your drone has. Enjoy!

I've testing these using ColorFabb PLA/PHA printed at 0.1mm layer height with a 0.4mm nozzle. Be very careful when pulling the blade off your printer's bed as it is fairly delicate.

EDIT: speaking of delicate the design has been updated with reinforced joints between the blades and the rotor since drone crashes and pulling the finished blades off the printer bed was breaking them off at this point. This updated design has now been tested and even survived a minor crash! Good enough for me!

Monoprice Select Mini 3D 15365

title: Nexus 7 (2013) Laser Cut QI Charging alignment Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I bought an inductive QI charger which is designed for cell phones, but also charges my Nexus 7 tablet. The only problem is that the tablet needs to be precisely centered to be charged, which takes a bit of effort to get exactly right, and if it's bumped off center it stops charging. So I built this frame that sits over the top of the charger and holds my tablet exactly centered over the charging coil.

It's made up of 3 layers of laser cut plywood, one around the charger, and two identical ones to frame the tablet. I stained it with an "Ebony" color after gluing the layers together.
The specific QI charger I have is this one: http://amzn.to/2Dlmxzy but if you have a differently shaped one you can just edit the center cutout of the charger base file.

You can see a video of it in action here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LNgHPEWmR14
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/LNgHPEWmR14" ></iframe>

remixed_from.title: Autolevel plate for CTC PI3 Pro B

title: CTC PRUSA i3 Pro B Bowden Drive with Autoleveling

description.text:
UPDATE 1/6/2018
The blasted 2mm glass worked great...for a while. Unfortunately the last print stuck too good to the blasted glass and some glass came off when I pulled the part off. So I'm I went back to the hardware store and picked up another piece of glass. Adhesion is just fine with Ammonia cleaned class (Windex or any off brand window cleaner), but not as good as the blasted glass.

UPDATE 12/30
I decided to print the STL and it turned out great. I put in 4 brass inserts and then mounted the whole thing from the back in the lower position via the brass inserts instead of the lower mounting holes. I also bead blasted the glass which seems to help with adhesion. Please note that the duct is adjustable via the oval mounting holes. I had to mount it in the all the way up position to give it clearance between the nozzle and the bed.

My CTC hotend broke and I was without a 3D printer. Luckily, I am in the process of building a HEVO and therefore I had the mount, hotend, extruder, retainer and duct already on hand. By drilling two extra holes and removing a little plastic near the X endstop flag in the mount, I made it fit the CTC carriage perfectly. Again, since my printer was down, I didn't design this in CAD and just modified the piece I had by hand and then created the STL for thingiverse so no guarantees that it will fit. I left a bridge in there for support that you will have to break out and I put in two mounting options; one way the way I mounted it by drilling holes, and another for mounting it with M3 brass fittings to lower the mount closer to the bed. The HEVO mount has the proximity probe spot already, so I figured I should add that sensor as well.

If you are ready for a double mod, keep reading...

Items Needed:

  • Soldering Iron
  • several connectors
  • connector wires (from breadboard)
  • Arduino IDE
  • an extra Arduino as ISP to update the bootloader on the CTC Aduino
  • Marlin firmware

BOM:

  • 1 x 5V NPN M12 inductive sensor
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/M12-4mm-detection-5VDC-NPN-NO-LJ12A3-4-Z-BX-5V-cylinder-inductive-proximity-sensor-switch/32553311139.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.iDrnoz

  • 3D Printer Accessories V6 J-Head Hotend RepRap Extruder for 1.75mm Filament, Direct Feed or Bowden. w/ 0.4mm Nozzle, 12V fan, and 3ft PTFE Bowden Tube
    ALPTA
    http://a.co/9PxYSl4

  • 8.5" x 8.5" galvanized 28ga metal plate to place between the hotbed and glass plate. This ensures that the sensor is triggered properly. Without it you will need to either not use glass or you are going to be very close to the nozzle level. Ferrous metals are the best at triggering proximity sensors, that's why I didn't use aluminium.

  • 8.5" x 8.5" x 0.880" glass plate. I prefer to print on glass.

  • Extruder of your choice (e.g. find one on thingiverse)

Process

  1. Prepare and install your material for your heat bed. Cut the galvanized plate with some metal shears to size. IMPORTANT: make sure the metal does not short out any contacts on the heated bed. You need to cut around those areas!.

  2. Get the glass plate from your a hardware store. They will cut it to size if you ask nicely. You need the corners angled to have room for the screw heads.

  3. Prepare and install the J hotend and proximity sensor with the extruder mount, retainer and duct from the HEVO project.

  4. Solder the 5V and Ground connections to the board. I chose to use add a connector for easy disconnect.

  5. Make a backup of the original settings. These were mine:

    15:07:46.286 : echo:Hardcoded Default Settings Loaded
    15:07:46.286 : echo:Steps per unit:
    15:07:46.287 : echo: M92 X78.74 Y78.74 Z2560.00 E105.00
    15:07:46.287 : echo:Maximum feedrates (mm/s):
    15:07:46.287 : echo: M203 X400.00 Y400.00 Z2.00 E45.00
    15:07:46.287 : echo:Maximum Acceleration (mm/s2):
    15:07:46.287 : echo: M201 X1400 Y1400 Z100 E80000
    15:07:46.287 : echo:Acceleration: S=acceleration, T=retract acceleration
    15:07:46.287 : echo: M204 S1400.00 T5000.00
    15:07:46.287 : echo:Advanced variables: S=Min feedrate (mm/s), T=Min travel feedrate (mm/s), B=minimum segment time (ms), X=maximum XY jerk (mm/s), Z=maximum Z jerk (mm/s), E=maximum E jerk (mm/s)
    15:07:46.287 : echo: M205 S0.00 T0.00 B20000 X13.50 Z0.30 E5.00
    15:07:46.287 : echo:Home offset (mm):
    15:07:46.287 : echo: M206 X0.00 Y0.00 Z0.00
    15:07:46.287 : echo:PID settings:
    15:07:46.287 : echo: M301 P19.86 I1.00 D98.93

  6. Upgrade your bootloader. Here is how to do it:
    NOTE: I simply used the standard SD card cable and plugged in bread board wires into the one end. So I didn't need to find a ribbon cable that I could cut up! I also added a pictures of the connectors.

  7. Time to download, configure and install Marlin. Use the GEEETECH example in the examples folder as a base. I attached my Configuration.h file here for reference with auto leveling enabled: https://www.thingiverse.com/download:4494314 . Using this config will consume 94% of the memory. So there is hardly anything left for additional features.

  8. Last but not least make sure you adjust the z-axis in the LCD until you get the nozzle in the correct location (mine was -0.25). Then make sure you save your settings.

*ANOTHER BENEFIT of UPGRADING YOUR FIRMWARE**
The CTC is over-extruding (at least mine was). In Cura I had set the correction in the start script, but with the new firmware I changed the E stepper from 105 to 95 in the configuration.h, so no more start code fix needed!

title: Roomba 880 Charging Base Ramp with Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My Roomba 880 would occasionally find it difficult to get back on the charging base and instead kick it around like a soccer ball.

I designed this ramp to clip onto the oval shaped stopper under the charging base and the frame goes around the base to hold it in place so that the Roomba doesn't drag it off when it backs up.

MP Select Mini v2

No

No

60

Depending on the size of the build area and your preference for gluing vs connectors, these files are the ones you want to look at:

  • Uncut, large build area > 185 mm:
    • 02_Roomba_Charging_Base_Frame.stl
  • Not for printing, just visual reference for placement of parts:

  • Cut, will need glue, 130 mm build area (If you want just the ramp without frame, you can get it from this file):

  • Not for printing, just visual reference for placement of parts:

  • Cut, but has connectors, so won't need glue, fits 120 mm build area (this is the only one I've tested):
    • 04_Roomba_Charging_Base_Frame_Connectors_120mm_1.stl
    • 04_Roomba_Charging_Base_Frame_Connectors_120mm_2.stl
  • Cut, but has connectors, so won't need glue, fits 135 mm build area:
    • 04_Roomba_Charging_Base_Frame_Connectors_135mm.stl

You may need to sand the male end of the connectors slightly to be able to pass it into the female end. I've designed the connectors to not come off if pulled apart, as a result you can only insert the connectors vertically, won't work if you push length-wise.

Don't sand too much, or you won't get a sturdy grip when you put it together.

At first I just designed a simple ramp for it that would clip on the oval shaped rubber stopper under the base. Unfortunately, the Roomba would pull it off while backing up at the start of the cleaning cycle. I didn't want to use glue to stick the ramp to the charging base, so added a frame around the ramp to secure it to the base.

You can follow the evolution of the design with the indexed prefixes of the file names.

  1. Started with an accurately measured outline of the charging base. Printed a single layer to confirm fit.
  2. Used the outline to create a 5 mm wide frame with a 6 deg ramp in the front.
  3. Since I have a small build area, I cut the final design into pieces. This is included in case anyone prefers gluing the pieces together.
  4. Added connectors to the pieces to allow them to be printed separately but can be connected together without the need to glue.

A simple box based on the excellent Ultimate Box Maker by Heartman, this is a box that holds an Arduino Mega, a Pixhawk, the RadioLink GPS and a 4-line display. Holes for USB for both boards. description.text:
This is a spacer/adapter for the UpLULA when using it to load the S&W M&P Shield 9mm and .40cal magazines. Without this spacer/adapter, the Shield's single-stack magazine shifts/wobbles while loading - making it annoying and cumbersome compared to loading the Shield magazines with the spacer/adapter in place.

The spacer/adapter was created in Fusion360 and supports the full length of the magazine inside the UpLULA. It has a nice friction fit that stays in place while loading, yet it's still easy to remove when you switch back to double-stack magazines.

No supports are needed if you print it base-down. It's very sturdy with 3 walls and 35% infill.

title: V-Wheel for OpenBuilds C-Beam using 608 skate bearing

description.text:
Two versions of a V-Slot wheel for OpenBuilds C-Beam or other matching aluminum extrusion.
One uses two 45 degree bevels as bearing surfaces, the other uses a completely rounded profile. Both parts use a standard 608 skate bearing that can be inserted from one side only. Both parts have an inner rim to place bearing in the center of the wheel.

Both wheels stand 10.5 mm when laying flat. Round wheel measures 32mm at greatest diameter, beveled wheel measures 30mm at greatest diameter. Both currently untested. Flat outer face of beveled wheel measures 6.5mm tall.

Holes should be 13mm (on center) away from the edge of the extrusion. Your mileage may vary.

description.text:
Here we have the second of many scale figures I have created for my 00 train layout.
The figures are firstly put together in MakeHuman setting up the armature and clothing, and a basic pose.
I then import into blender to get the final pose that I require, I do this by importing other items that will be used by the final printed figure. This ensures the figure will fit the the surrounding items correctly.
The figure is posed so that the hands hold the wheelbarrow correctly.
Finally imported into my CAD software where I convert everything into solids, and orientated the model on the supports to be printed.
Models have support structure as part of the stl.

title: Blade Torrent prop guards & Roll Cage

description.text:
My take on a 3d printed blade guard for the Blade Torrent 110. I have also designed a roll cage of sorts to help offset some of the weight gained from this design.

Each blade guard is roughly 1 gram heavier than the stock blade guards but they also have 1 more support than stock. This will hopefully decrease the number of times i have to change out the blade guards. The roll cage is roughly 3 grams lighter than the stock canopy so it's about a wash

I printed these out in PETG upside down from how they would mount the torrent with supports. I tried printing them both ways and upside down seams to result in a better print.

I moved the video tx to above the receiver and used double stick tape to hold it in place. Used the the original canopy mount holes with a 2mm bolt and a plastic washer to hold the roll cage in place.

With petg they appear to have about the same flex as the stock blade guards.

you can still remove and replace blade guards with blade on the motors.

I have not been able to test as of yet because i have a bad motor i need to replace

Updated to include a file for the .2 version that has thinner fence posts, I just thought it looked better. Looking forward to being able to make it much prettier in the future!

My friend from Thailand was telling me all about spirit houses used for worship of gods and/or ancestors, basically tokens for good fortune and a focal point to have a physical place and object for spiritual thoughts/activities (kind of like having a personal shrine or altar). Some people have large and elaborate ones and others smaller, more humble ones, and you can keep them either within your home or (more commonly) in the yard outside. You place small figures in the house to represent the spirits you'd like to have come inhabit the house, and then you light incense, and possibly candles sometimes, and leave little offerings while talking/praying to the spirit(s) who live in your spirit house, asking for their presence to protect your home and its inhabitants, or imploring your departed family to watch over you. She showed me pictures. They are so beautiful. I was fascinated!

I decided I needed one of my own, because who doesn't need a little intervention by friendly spirits in their lives? I wanted to try my hand at designing one for printing, so other people could share too. I live in an apartment with no yard so I made a windowsill-sized model. If you live in Thailand, or are Catholic or Neo-Pagan, or just in general have a home altar/shrine, you could add this to it as a holder for incense and invite whatever you believe in to come visit it and watch over you. If you are not any of these things but like candles and/or incense and want a little holder for them related to a cool cultural and spiritual practice, you could also print this.

Once printed, my intent is to use my rotary tool to drill a tiny hole for the sticks of incense into the indented place on the base- I think this will be way easier than trying to build that into the design. Once this has been done, I can either push incense sticks into the hole or place a small candle in the indent. Hopefully, the indent will catch most of the ashes, but we'll see. The small platform is to place offerings of food or flowers or whatnot. The hollow in the house can have a small doll or figure placed inside. You can paint it or leave it as is or whatever!

I intend to improve on this design over time as my skills improve, just wanted to see what I could accomplish now with TinkerCAD. Please feel free to fiddle, I'd love to see others' interpretations. Make it customizable, text you can alter on the archway, add a doghouse for the spirit's dog, give it flying buttresses, whatever you want. My goal is to make this much more ornate and pretty. And er, looking more like a little house and less like something a three year old drew...

Hopefully your friendly house spirit will not mind living in budget manufactured housing...

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3JaWGOlY5af
It's all just TinkerCAD shape presets, I was more or less just messing around- I'd love to see other people add to and improve on it!

title: Thomas the Train Engine Face Lego

description.text:
Designed to interface with blocks that have a center pip, such as #6115080. I remixed this with Creator set 31054 in mind.

It can be FDM printed (I did it) with an extremely tight resolution (0.05mm layer height or smaller), but obviously this would really shine on a SLA/DLP printer.

comments.text: I have been looking for something like this, but I am wondering about the size when attaching to Lego. I want to have this in the size of a 4x4 round plate for my Thomas Lego-model. Is that possible without changing the model?
comments.author: HenrikLego

comments.text: It would have to change quite a bit.  This was designed to lock onto a single, center pip, and the 4x4 rounds have ten pips and a center hole (If I recall).  You could, in theory, jam a 1x1 round into the center between the four centermost pips, and then lock a embiggened version of this face onto that, but you'd end up with a slight gap you'd need to fill somehow.  Otherwise, you'd need to flatten and remodel the back of this appropriately.
comments.author: HenrikLego

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

description.text:
I had access to larger 8020 extrusion so I remixed the motor mounts and top Z rod holders to fit the larger extrusions.

Regular AM8 is 20mmx40mm
these parts fit the 25mmx50mm profile.

The parts such as PSU and CPU holders and corner bracketsI have printed from the original and will make work by sloting the holes as needed.
If I get more time I will finish the whole set in 25-50 format.

Importaint: Width wise some extrusions must be 5mm longer.
so parts list is
2x440mm
2x340mm
3x318mm These are longer because of the extra width of the extrusion 20mm-25mm difference.

I have completed my frame and am back making parts again.
The frame is extremely ridged and there is no detectable flex during printing.
Parts are much more accurate than when printed using the stock frame.

Y Motor mount comes in two styles. one piece and two piece. one piece might be a bit stiffer but is a pain to install. I also didn't use the bolt behind the motor. impossible to tighten.

I have started to reverse engineer the FDM printable parts using Solidworks. It would have been Much Much easier if I could have just imported .STL files and made some adjustments.
I tried free cad => to .step files => to Import to Solidworks. That only marginally works sometimes.
I have just spent hours over the 2017 holidays to see how far I could get.

comments.text:
I have been printing on my AM8_25-50 REMIX for a couple weeks now.
My benchy print is a very tight ship!
Frame wobble transmitted to the print head and shown in parts as wall ripples is a thing of the past.
comments.author: ARands

comments.text:
I Had the holidays off in 2017 and spent lots of that time honing my skills at remixing the original AM8 frame build to fit a totally different size aluminum extrusion. This build is meant for the 8020_25-50 extrusion. So instead of 20x40mm its 25x50mm.
as of Friday the 30th I still have not assembled my own and do not have all the bugs worked out.
comments.author: ARands

description.text:
Quite handy tool organizer mounted directly on frame and power supply.
Just be careful when mount. To long screw will damage power supply and give You electric shock.
One of photo is from previous version.

print_settings.Notes:: 1.6mm wall thickness with supports everywhere. It printed some support in the holes on the cap but that didn't really effect the way it went together.

title: Anet A8 E3D V6 Bowden Dual Extruder Mount Pruisa i3 Clone X Carriage

description.text:
Updated 1-18-18 READY TO GO!

See it run here: https://youtu.be/Nrn9100MQbY

See my Rear Sensor Mount version here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2763157

All instructions are for the Anet A8.

Reduced some sizes, moved some things and cleaned it up. I added some zip tie holes in the sides and improved tolerances. I made slotted holes because my printed X mounts changed the dimensions a bit.

I have printed, installed and now used this part. Below are instructions on how to set it up.

I printed them with 1.8mm wall and 30% fill. I also made a set at 1.2mm wall and 15% fill that worked perfectly. Both in PLA.

This includes guides like my thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2732685 built into the mount.

Get the latest Skynet3D firmware from https://github.com/thijsk/Skynet3d and please update your firmware as follows:

Enable RAMPS boards, this is for the common ones like https://goo.gl/XW91zh [Amazon.com link] PLEASE pay attention and be sure to choose the correct code for your motherboards. See boards.h in the Skynet firmware for a list.

define MOTHERBOARD BOARD_RAMPS_14_EEB

Enable dual extruders:

define EXTRUDERS 2

Offsets for the extruders:

define HOTEND_OFFSET_X {0.0, 35.00}
define HOTEND_OFFSET_Y {0.0, 0.00}

For the probe it's :

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -35 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 4 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.5 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle Set this to your machine. I used a .5mm thick print put between the bed and probe with the nozzle touching the bed to start.]

You also need to set travel limits:

// Travel limits after homing (units are in mm)

define X_MAX_POS 240
define X_MIN_POS -15
define Y_MAX_POS 230
define Y_MIN_POS -13
define Z_MAX_POS 230
define Z_MIN_POS 0

And probe point offsets:

// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 27
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20

See https://goo.gl/NkkGsb [3D print wiki] for the best instructions I have found so far on how to set your probe Z offset. I did this using the terminal in Octoprint via to Raspberry Pi on the printer.

I am running RAMPS 1.4 with Skynet firmware.

Anyways, this is getting out of hand so here's the important stuff:

Many models to choose from!

  • No sensor mount
  • 18mm sensor
  • 12mm sensor
  • 8mm sensor

Then choose you cap:

  • 2 stock fans with chain mount
  • 2 stock fans no chain mount
  • No fans no chain mount
  • No fans with chain mount
  • if you need them there's fan spacers too. I found my duct hit the extruder.

If you go with one with a chain mount I have included the X axis chain links from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2193695 This is what I remixed from. You may get the other end mount from here or use mine at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2762145

Then choose you print settings:

  • Choose .AMF or .STL. I found .AMF more accurate and works in Cura.

  • Made one at .4mm Nozzle, .2mm step, 1.6mm wall and 30% fill worked great

  • Made a second at .4mm nozzle, .2mm step, 1.2mm wall and 15% fill, worked just as good.

  • Do your own of course! You guys know what's what.

You will need:

1) E3D style extruders
2) RAMPS 1.4 or 1.5
3) Marlin/Skynet firmware
4) 40mm M4 Screws and Nuts for the cap, 3 of them
5) 50mm blower fan
6) Wires, connectors, crimpers, and a soldering iron helps.

I have made a guide in PDF form available here https://goo.gl/1s8jSR for setting the offsets. You will need a serial connection to your printer and I found using Octoprint is really easy.

Here's a crapCAD schematic of the optocoupler board I made to run the 12v probe completely isolated from the RAMPS board.

Thank you! Enjoy and please like, comment and share!

description.text:
An useful pen holder for the Note 8 Spen, with this you can draw and write a lot better.
There is a cut for pen button.

Printable without supports pulling down - 3,5 mm model on Z axis, pen still usable.

Better results with 0,1 layer height, speed 2600 mm/min and brim 10 outlines

Designed for 3mm material and intended to be glued together. Should fit precisely in a 300x200mm laser machine like k40 chinese laser cutters.

The spaces between on the base and top are very forgiving, mostly because it's far easier to loosely fit the pieces in top and bottom if they aren't super snug. I wanted to leave the top open so that light would come through each layer. Also, the original design from OBUQ had spacing between the layers to give depth and I wanted to preserve that.

green lines should be cut last. Order of panels goes from top left then down.

NOTE: Some of the cutouts are very tiny and congested. You'll want to make sure the laser goes all the way through on these so they come out with the least resistance. Some of my trees also disconnected at the finest points, but I didn't see a real problem with that as most of them are protected behind other layers.

title: EZ Brass Breech for Nerf Longshot  Lipless Systems
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Lipless Brass Breech for the Nerf Longshot.
Fits 9/16 Brass tubes into the printed breech.

Original design by Flechette Spectre.

This particular support model has been tested using CFD and has shown to withstand 16kg of force on the support without failure (very far below failure level).
HOWEVER, computer simulation and real-life application differ at times, and I would not be responsible if you break anything.

V2 Changes made includes:

  • Redesigned Fatigue supports. (stronger and allows for ease of jam clearance, if any)
  • Integrated Cyclone Cup (improves air flow and increases FPS)
  • Double O-Ring Seal (Keeps tube lubricated and improves seal from tube to breech)
  • Variable Brass Lip (brass will stick out of the front, you choose which length you want to cut it off at. this affects how much overlap there is on the front barrel)

V3 Changes made includes:

  • Redesigned Fatigue supports. (stronger and allows for ease of jam clearance, if any)
  • Integrated Cyclone Cup (improves air flow and increases FPS)
  • Double O-Ring Seal (Keeps tube lubricated and improves seal from tube to breech)
  • reduced breech length by 1mm (improves ease of installation and feeding)
  • Fixed Brass Lip (insert 9/16 to the end of the breech, trace out the lip and dart finger, and cut accordingly)

title: Slime Rancher Dry Reef Rocks and Trees

description.text:
Watch here: https://youtu.be/NxbNh-zUnMQ

Adding to my 3D Printed slime collection this time is the Dry Reef Environment. This closes out the 3 part series on the Dry Reef. I think I might eventually add a 4th part with Gordos and a background sky and ground. We'll see.

I modeled the background rocks in Fusion 360, then I added textures in ZBrush using the surface noise features. I modeled the rocks and trees in ZBrush and added textures to those as well.

I sliced them all in Simplify3D and printed them on the CR10 and Prusa MK2 using PLA. No sanding or anything. Just primer and paint.

I'll be adding more to this Slime Rancher series, let me know what you want to see!

I combined the x-axis rod holder with the motor mount and the belt tensioner. This reduces the width of the printer. You will need a 430mm 2020 V-slot extrusion for this, instead of 500 mm of the original thing I remixed it from.

UPDATED: Feb 8, 2018
I have made short and long versions of the carriage, utilizing one or two bearings. Since the long version extends downwards, it should not affect the maximum print height.

I also made versions without endstops. If you need an endstop for these, you can use the one from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2439194

Last but not least, the design includes "anti-wobble" protection for the Z Axis. The holes for the lead screw nuts and their mounting screws are larger than needed. I did it on purpose.

You have to tighten the screws just enough, so the nut can move freely on the horizontal but be steady on the vertical. This way, it can absorb the wobble of the leadscrew. Be sure to use locknuts. Normal nuts tend to unscrew themselves from the vibrations over time.

Finally, for less friction I also used these: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2216161 printed in PLA as shims.

Here is a small video demo of the anti-wobble feature: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_BI2iKsqJhs

author: NirViaje

title: Prusa MK3 Einsy RPi Zero Access

description.text:
Update 2018/02/13: Alternate Base with heat bed nylon support holder added back in.

Update 2018/01/28: Alternate Cover with clip to hold camera adapter.

This is a rework of Prusa's "Einsy-base" file from Github. I knocked out an opening to access the RPi Zero, reworked the vents, and added a removable cover. There is also an added slot to access the lower screw used to mount the base to the frame. The Pi cover is held on by screws commonly used on computer case fans, like these. https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01LLKY3GO

The Prusa original Einsy-base is printed in PETG, at .35mm. I printed mine in PLA at .2mm. Prusa Control sliced it beautifully. So no need to get fancy slicing. The MK3 really is an amazing printer!

Alternate Base: Originally I removed the nylon filament holder on the heatbed cable in lieu of extra vents. The nylon filament wasn't staying in place for me very well, and the zip tie seemed to be doing the job OK. However, there was a request to add it back, and it wasn't too much work. So there is now a "b" variant that has the nylon filament boss. The part has a "Wb" mark on the back, "W" for Rpi Zero W, and "b" for the b variant.

Alternate Cover: In order to use a camera with the Pi Zero, an adapter must be used to connect the mini camera cable to a regular cable. Apparently the mini cables all come in mini lengths. Most installs I have seen, including my own up till now, left the adapter just floating around loose. Couple with the extra 24" cable, the camera cable was getting would up with the X-Axis wire loom. This alternate cover partially fills in one of the covers slots, so a clip can be used to hold the adapter up out of the way, on the cover its self. This neatly folds up the mini cable, and points the longer cable up and out of the way. Adafruit is the only supplier I have found yet that has an adpater/extender to lengthen a camera cable with a Pi Zero. https://www.adafruit.com/product/3671

One of the pictures also shows a set of brackets I have published that routes the camera cable neatly around the X stepper, and the wire loom. This bracket is part of the RPi camera mount I put together, that uses Ball and Socket links to position the camera relative to the print head, on the X-Axis stepper. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2773810

Notice: License changed to GNU GPL, to match Prusa's original source license.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm - .30mm

Infill:

20%

title: Prusa i3 MK2S Rambo Clip for Extruder Cables

description.text:
A few of us with MK2S kits received nylon cables that were roughly two centimeters too short. This means the nylon cables are not seated in the rambo case, which means the extruder cables aren't being supported.

So I made this. It may not be perfect and you may have to adjust it to fit your needs, but it works for me. The half hole for the nylon cable was a failed attempt to tighten the nylon cable down, but it also saves a bit of space and seems to work just fine.

If you have issues with the supports, try printing it on it's side (as provided). Worked much better for me.

description.text:
In the photos section you'll see 3x3 maze cube, but with a script you can generate any size maze. You just need to draw it in 2D. 1st I drawn on paper and then converted to an ASCII drawing in OpenSCAD app which then converted to a 3D model.

Everything is highly configurable. E.g. you'll probably want to change the size of the metal ball. I had 11mm diameter ball, but online you can order other sizes as well.

Pull Requests with your designs are welcome on this Github repository: https://github.com/ViliusKraujutis/3D-designs/tree/master/3D-labyrinth

Demo video is presented here: https://youtu.be/9_NgOfyto4M
This is a remix of a design by Derek Chong, for the pod of a 130mm mini quad. Original model not posted on Thingiverse. Added jigsaw snap-fit for two halves, extra supports and handles M3 hardware.

Three of these bumpers hold the 120 mm glass and build plate steady on a Monoprice Mini Delta. Bumpers prevent bed from shifting horizontally. Scale to fit, (A 64 mm wide part printed at 62.5 mm on my MP Mini Delta.).
Additional: Fixed MP Mini Delta size issue using Gcodes M92 to raise XY&Z stepper values and then M500 to save. 64 mm model then printed accurately. Original values were 56.5 steps per mm and new values 57.6. Also needed to adjust end stops within .1 mm before getting decent first layer. Calibrating Extrusion was next as 100 mm of extrusion only gave 96. Used M503 to view changes.

This a Magic Flashing Paddle, and it is a magic trick that is very visual, and great for close-up magic. It is a simple trick that you can learn in about 15 minutes. A paddle motion is a super small rolling motion between your index finger and thumb, which rolls the paddle while pretending to show both sides. Link to video below

author: Saccco

description.text:
My grandfather has a holiday-house which is not connected to the sewage system. It therefore has a cesspool with a mixer inside that turns once or twice a day for some time at 1000 rpm in both directions. The original mixer came off and sunk to the bottom, so the best option was to print him a new one. It had to:

  • fit through a hole of 12.5cm (<5 inch), so the maximum diameter is limited
  • be able to function in two directions, so the design is symmetrical
  • not clog or jam, so the design has smooth edges
  • not break, so thick fins
  • not dissolve , so I printed the final design in Polymaker PC-max (polycarbonate) (perhaps ABS is also a good choice)

It has 4 M8 mounting holes at 25 and 30mm from the M10 center hole.

remixed_from.title: i3 A8 Badass DiggityDank MK8 Carriage

description.text:
A remix of the Badass DiggityDank Extruder by LittleMrJ. Found that the carriage would warp a lot when the carriage is warmed up over a long period of time by the extruder motor. Solved by beefening it up and creating some spacing for heat to escape elsewhere.

Other changes include a screw hole for adjusting the x-axis endstop engagement some minor chamfering of some edges.

*Update: Depending on how your heating and thermistor end is positioned, it may slightly melt the underside of the carriage. Might help to put some sort of reflective tape or to move the heat block.

A new X carriage that fits the dual extruder from Ali-Express!

PROTOTYPE- NOT FINAL DESIGN!!

title: Prusa i3 MK2 (MK3?) Spool Holder / Spulenhalter

description.text:
translated with Google translator:

Hello,

The original spool holder from Prusa Research for the MK2 did not convince me.
This is my variant of a spool holder for this printer.
I certainly tend to construct things like that a bit over-stably, but that does not have to be a mistake.
(At this spool holder the printer could be worn too ...)

Besides the printed parts you still need:

2 pieces M3 square nuts
2 pieces M3 x 30mm cylinder head bolts
1 piece 8mm threaded rod (about 200mm)
2 pieces M8 nuts
1 piece M8 washer (24mm, optional)

The assembly is more than easy ...

The spools themselves are best placed on corresponding adapters on the axle.
like this:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:734279

or this:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:601401

The .stl files are optimized for printing with 0.2mm layer height, 0.3 should also fit.
The screw holes in "part_b" are intentionally not continuous, this is to facilitate the print.
The thin membrane (0.2mm) can be easily pierced after printing.

The clip effectively prevents unwanted movement of the spool on the axle.

title: Printmate 3D and BQ Hephestos 1 E3D update

description.text:
Some time ago I had some issues with my Printmate. The wooden Extruder/Hotend mount got some play this resulted in not very good prints. So I played around a bit and came up with a complete new Marlin, New Hotend, BLTouch and Hotend/Extruder mount. Funny thing that this mount also fits (nearly) the BQ Hephestos version 1 (I don´t know if version 2 is the same). I also updated to a very standard Anycubic Extruder (I will change this...) mount and now I am using a bowden setup. You can screw the Extruder on top ofthe frame on the Printmate, for the BQ I designed an extra Holder. Mount the holder on the back of the top frame with two cable-ties. And yes, this setup can only be used with a bowden setup, but it works! If you update to for example a bon tech extruder it works even better, this is what I will do... if time is there...
So you find the "x" parts for the BQ and the Printmate. There are two version for the clamp, one with BLTouch mount and one without. I also uploaded the hex files for the Printmate with the Extruder Steps for the Anycubic. But you can change all steps/mm directly from the LCD. The accelerations and jerks a pretty low, you can set these higher, absolutely! < See pictures.
Also fou find the configuration.h for the Printmate.

One thing (!), the BLTouch is screwed to the clamp, one M3 Screw with a nut and the other one is a "plastic-cut-screw", a short M3 screw should also fit. Please try out.

The Firmware is set up for the PRINTMATE and BL-Touch, so you will need a G29 command after G28 (home all axis) in your starting gcode.
My starting gcode:
G28
G29
G1 F4000 X0 Z30
G92 E0
G1 F300 E40
G92 E0
G1 F6000 Y100 Z2

Retraction is now 4,00mm with 45mm/s on my Printmate, the Extrusion Multiplier is on my Printer now 1,04 with PLA...

Next thing!... You see the 30mm and 40mm Fans mounted with two very nice fan holders. I downloaded these from builda3dprinter.eu , go to Information > download > 3D Files. Very good and nice guy behind this shop. I also have some Delta´s from builda3dprinter and I like these parts very much. But this are not my parts so I´m not going to upload these...

By the way, I also updated the X and Y axis with Nema17 Vibration dampers and the Y axis with drylin Igus linear bearings...

And finally....You may need some additional screws (maybe)...

I hope this helps you out a bit. I really love my Printmate. This was my second 3D Printer and was used quite a lot. Now you can update your Printmate and stay updated.
If something is not right please let me know. I did this because of fun doing it and for sure I´m not a professional... so be patient with me :-D.

Printmate3D

45

Please try the best Orientation when printing these parts. The Hotend should fit nice into the x holder and the clamp. I printed in PLA and about 35mm/s.

description.text: A remix of DPGDesigns remix. The original duct from Tevo was flush with the side of the fan shroud. The original remix of the duct wraps under the fan shroud to better aim the air flow at the printed part. My printer has an "ear" on the bottom of the shroud which prevented the remix part to sit flush with the bottom of the fan shroud. This remix has a relief notch in the side of the duct to allow it to sit flush as intended. Thanks to DPGDesigns for the original remix.

description.text:
A simple cable holder/spool. One of my first Fusion360-designed 'things' I've made. I printed it on my new Snapmaker.

You can print it any size you like by scaling. I designed it to be 10cm between the center of the 'arms' (each 10mm thick), and 70mm between the center of the (4mm) screw holes. This should work for normal AC 110/230V cabling. For thinner cabling (USB?) you can print it resized to 50% if you like.

V2: now with a small fillet on the base of the arms. Looks a bit smoother, imho.

Vertical Laboratory.
Click-on panels for electronic devices. The board plates are not just hung. You can use them right in the panel and build many projects on the wall.
However you can easily remove the modules by hand and use them on your desktop.
To remove the panels you need to pull from two sides while sliding the plate, to avoid your expensive electronics to fall. Boards can be mounted in four different orientations.
Te attachment/detachment method is always possible just from the front side of the panel, so you don't need to remove the pegboard from the wall in any moment.
Everyone can have an electronics laboratory at home/office/mancave using a metal pegboard. Use also magnetic labels to identify your project parts.
This pegboard has 4.75mm holes separated 26 mm. The model files are in Sketchup, so they are not parametric and major work has to be done to change the hole dimensions and step.
The designs include the detachable board spacers, so you just need some screws to hold the board on the plate.
Each board also features a removable label support compatible with DYMO labeling system to better organize your projects. Just bend twice the label suppor by hand to remove it.
Use appropiate colors to easily identify your module families: blue for arduino, red for raspberry pi, green for beaglebone green, etc.
In many designs, the boards can be mounted in two different directions, depending on which side you want the label.

This system has been designed for commom electronic development oards as well as GROVE modules ( https://www.seeedstudio.com/category/Grove-c-1003.html ) that have been provided to TaISLab ( http://taislab.uma.es ) by SeeedsStudio.

So far, the set of included plates include:

  • Arduino Mega form factor boards
  • Arduino UNO form factor boards
  • Beaglebone green
  • Raspberry PI (1,2,3) model B
  • ESP32 with OLED display
  • Suppor panels for grove modules
  • Velcro cable ties
  • many more ...

The system has been featured on HackADay.com :
https://hackaday.com/2018/01/01/electronics-workbench-goes-vertical-with-pegboard-mounting/

3-1-2018: Added the rest of designs.

The panels are inexpensive and can be purchased in Amazon in different countries:

https://www.amazon.com/Simonrack-Kit-Panelclick-Garden-Green/dp/B00RD874HE/ref=nav_custrec_signin?ie=UTF8&qid=1515014106&sr=8-11&keywords=simonrack+panel&

https://www.amazon.com/Simonrack-Panelclick-Shelf-Grey-Dark/dp/B00RD896NY/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1515014172&sr=8-4&keywords=simonrack+panel

Good luck!

description.text:
After having made my new settlers version 2.0 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2525047) I wanted to create a storage box for those tiles that would look a little less "industrial" than the fully 3d-printed one I allready made (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1482713).
As we do have a great fablab in town (https://www.fablabs.io/labs/map) where you can use a lot of different tools, I decided to create a new box that can be made with a laser cutter and this is the result, with that I'm pretty happy with :-)

IMPORTANT: Before you start this project, make sure that you use materials (wood & acrylic-glass) with a thickness of 5 mm!

There are as well some 3d-printed parts that come along with the design. These are the parts you need to print:
1 x storage card holder
1 x storage card holder – badge (to be glued together with the storage card holder)
1 x set of storage player parts
1 x storage center part (single- or multicolored)
2 x storage core parts

For the lasercutter you need the following parts to cut / engrave with a material thickness of 5 mm:
1 x top plexiglass: Use acrylic-glass, cut the outer parts and do engrave the writing and the picture
1 x top-part: Cut the outer parts and engrave the flower-ornaments
1 x middle-part: Cut the outer- and inner-parts
2 x bottom-parts: Cut the outer- and inner-parts

ASSEMBLING :
Here's a short description how I assembled those parts :
• Sand all the parts after having them cutted with the laser-cutter
• Apply a layer of wood stain to all parts, except the sides with the flower-ornaments and the acrylic-glass of course and let everything dry
• Sand all the parts (not with to much pressure, just to make them smooth)
• Apply 3 layers of clear coat to all the wooden parts and let them dry
• Use glue to put all the parts together by applying the glue on the "outer-spikes" of each part. Make sure you enter the two 3d-printed parts (storage core) inside the wooden bottom-parts before closing them in with the front-pieces!
• For the top-part you need some extra 6 mm round wood. Cut 4 parts with a lenght of 1 cm. Then turn around the engraved acrylic-glass and place it on top of the wooden top-part. Then insert the round wood-parts in the four wholes by adding some glue.

Don't hesitate to ask me questions about how to build this box if the description should not be clear enough.

Big THX to Kurt who helped me build this project by teaching me how to use a laser cutter and how to generate the models. Fablab bern roules :-)

These are the three main pieces for a liquid ring vacuum pump.  I have to do some more refined models with dimensions of actual bearings.  However the concept is here and I will make it completely functional as soon as my maker bot shows up.  
Basically you bolt the lid on with the impeller inside the chamber.  Fill the chamber about half way with water and as the impeller spins the water is flung out evenly around the chamber.  Since the impeller is offset, the void space between the impeller blades and the water changes size as it goes around creating a pocket of compression at the top and suction at the bottom.
Note this is a concept mock up.  I will refine it into something functional once my makerbot shows up.

Here's my derivative of Mattraptions' desk lamp, with added M3 screw holes. Some parts will still need to be edited and beefed up, but I thought I'd share it anyway. An alternative to anyone who likes screws instead :D

Extra hardware needed: 8 x 10 mm M3 screws
2 x 15 mm M3 screws
1 x 35 mm M3 screw The base still needs work to mount strong, and I've found using two 10mms from both sides instead of one long screw works better and looks a little nicer aesthetically.

description.text:
I recently replaced an Aero Bed air mattress with a Coleman equivalent. The Aero Bed had an integral air pump but Coleman replacement did not. I removed the pump from the Aero Bed and designed an adapter that allows the pump to interface with and inflate the Coleman mattress.

Attached are two models:

  • Adapter that marries with Coleman Air Mattress inflation nozzles.

Alternate Design

description.text:
A modified version of 3DSage's Alien cube - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1741021

I wanted one with the design on all six faces, and that I could choose the orientation of said faces, so i imported the side piece from his into TinkerCAD, messed around with it a bit, and beveled all the edges so you could rotate it by 90 degrees if you wanted. I also made a mirrored version. Then I made a central block that they would fit onto, and made adjustments to his lid and lid diffuser to make them fit.

i would suggest that you set your printer to have a short z hop on movements, because there are a lot of movements when printing the faces, and i swear i printed about 13 of them before turning z hop on, and they almost all failed, but after i turned it on, i got 5 good ones printed, with no problems other than them needing a bit of a shave when they were done. didn't even need to sand them cause i liked the way that they looked with the concentric surface fill pattern.

All the parts are in individual files, along with alternate lid and face designs using the voronoi shape generator from Tinkercad. I suggest printing the core and lid diffuser with either translucent or white filament if you're going to put lights in it.

I've printed one, and can confirm that it looks pretty neat. i printed mine entirely with clear pla, and then spray painted the faces and lid, then after they dried, glued the thing together with super glue, and now it's just sitting on my desk while i wait for the LED's and bits that i ordered to arrive.

IMPORTANT!- bwillz85 had trouble with the core part, where the first perimeter layer, which should be on the first layer, was being placed on the second layer. which if you're not completely new to 3D printing, you'll understand is bad. he fixed it by cutting a tiny bit (.5 mm) off of the bottom of the model, so if you have had that part fail, check to see if you're getting the same problem.

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Supports wont make a difference for the faces and lid.

You'll have to remove the supports from the underside of the core cube, and then it will probably require some sanding, notably on the edges. after that, glue the faces on (except the lid) and then throw some LED's inside, i guess?

comments.text: Good Print, but in order to get the Core to print, you need to cut about .50 off the bottom of the model to get the first layer to go down. When viewed in the slicer you can see that the first outer perimeter never goes down on layer 1. It tries to place the outer perimeter on the second layer. This caused the base to come off when printing. Thought this might help others. Used S3D with Prusa I3 MK3. I'll upload "Made" pictures soon. Thank you for this remix.
comments.author: bwillz85

comments.text: that's not a problem i ever had, and i've printed 3 of these. it might be the different slicer software? i'm using ultimaker cura 3.1.0 i think. and a different printer. and also i printed it with a brim, because there is a very very thin edge touching the build plate and i was having problems with it peeling itself off and warping. but yeah, that is very strange, and i'm glad you got it to work. I'll put a note about that on the main page.

description.text:
The charm of an ePaper display is its capability to show something without any power and using power only when the display changes. This enables to make IoT or other displays don’t require an ugly power cord and needs to be charged only once for moths.

Unfortunately there aren’t too many such displays suitable for makes on the market. (https://blog.squix.org) & (https://www.tindie.com/products/cxandy/azsmz-epaper-29-with-usb-to-serial/?pt=ac_prod_search) introduced recently a 2.9” one.

I tried to give the housing a bit of a conservative but today’s look. The outcome reminds a bit to a thermostat – which is pretty ok because that is exactly a similar form: “It hangs somewhere on the wall”, looks convenient, has a technical approach but isn’t dominant on the wall.

The printing was surprisingly difficult. Sanding the edges might become required (which I didn’t made so far – as you can see on the pictures). But then major is wrapping. I assume the structure of the front doesn’t hold that well on the bed as it’s broken. However probably it is a good idea to print it with PLA instead of ABS as I did.

description.text:
This is a remix of two great products:

Mx SMD component strip holder
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2186862

SMD Strip Dispenser Tray for Mx SMD Roll
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2717152

I was really impressed by how these two products came together. When I was testing out the holder, a few SMD pieces fell out of the strip, and I had nowhere to save them alongside the strip storage container they belong to. I did see that Mx also has an insert for such storage, but I didn't want a separate box for just a few loose pieces.

My solution was to stretch both the original strip holder and the dispenser cover to allow for a bin that could hold the loose pieces. When closed up, you'll have the loose and sealed pieces all in one spot.

After printing my sample, I added a label to the "top" side so that you don't accidentally open the container upside-down and spill those little SMD pieces everywhere. There's also a small recess to put a printed label or sharpie marker label on that "up" side.

author: pbechard

description.text:
I bought my daughter a gymnastics air mattress for Christmas, and it did not come with a pump. I assumed I could use a standard nozzle to inflate it, but it actually had a cool inflation port that kept air from coming out after you remove the pump nozzle. After a bit of research, I found out that it is a Halkey Roberts valve, commonly used on stand up paddle boards. I found an adapter on Thingiverse that would allow me to hook up a compressor (I have one, but this Air Track requires a pretty low PSI, and is too loud to use to pump up a Christmas gift and not wake the kids. I also found a Coleman pump nozzle that fits my model.

So I took the two models, spliced them together, and added some wings (the print I first had was so tight I could barely get it in and out of the HR valve, so the wings help with leverage). I also moved the inner piece (that pushed the valve open) towards the front tabs, since on my Air Track, it was too far away and didn't push open the valve when it was latched on.

I printed on my Anet A8 with supports. Be careful when removing the supports from the top tabs, as the first print I did I snapped off the latch when doing so. Also, the seal of hard plastic to hard plastic did let air escape, so I made a make shift gasket our of some rubber bands wrapped around the point where the two surfaces meet. It wasn't a perfect seal, but it will do until I can find a rubber washer with the right diameter to go around the valve.

comments.text: Hi, I think it's a great design, thanks for your contribution. A question if you can please, Could you tell me how you got your plastic pieces to have that perfect polish?
comments.author: fran_solo

comments.text:
Hey man how's things
The finish as actually pretty easy. The whole model is sanded and primed and flatted until you have a smooth surface.
All the parts are sprayed with normal rattle cans from your car accessory shop, the black is satin black and the cream colour is, well cream.
When you have the parts painted the black is finished by using a small amount of tamiya silver paint rubbed on very lightly with a cloth. The silver tends to rub off on all the high spots leaving that worn finish. The cream was treated with a black wash which is then almost all wiped back off leaving the black in all the cracks and crevises.
These methods pop the detail out are are really easy to do. The trick is don't over do it. Less is more.
There are a ton of videos on youtube explaining these techniques in more detail.
Good luck!
comments.author: fran_solo

comments.text: Thank you very much for your advice. I will try to have reference to the finish you give your figures printed in 3d. By the way, the trick of using tamiya silver paint and a cloth would never have fallen into doing so. Thank you very much, if you ever need anything, let me know.

description.text:
I left off one of the two top covers to show the electronics. I also upgraded to APEX 1/8 scale RC car off-road wheels. This required I make 17mm nuts to attach the stepper motor D-shaft to the wheels. I also used Fusion 360 to create the Stealth Remix side panel to fill the unneeded holes. Later as I was trying to plug a USB cable into the Leonardo board to change the code - I found I needed to drill a 1/2 inch hole into the side panel for the cable, or print one SidePanelWithUSB hole, and the other panel without that hole.

I love the look of the s199 B-Robot Stealth Remix.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Editing STL

I used Fusion 360 to import the B-Robot side panel, and filled the unused holes with rectangles.

I used Fusion 360 to import the B-Robot off-road 12mm nut. I scaled that nut up to 17mm and then reduced the scaled thickness back to the original 5mm. Then I copied the 12mm nut into the exact center of the new 17mm nut. This gave me the same D-keyed hole size for the servo shaft as the 12mm nut for my 17mm nut.

The resulting 17mm nut STL had to be repaired by the Netapp web repair app to make a single solid STL for printing

remixed_from.title: Arduino Uno Case for Adafruit Ethernet Shield

title: RFM Gateway with Ethernet Shield W5100 on a Arduino Uno

description.text:
This is a housing for an Arduino Uno with an Ethernet Sheild. The lid has ports for the reset button, an antenna and 2 leds.

v1.1 (Shown in the pictures) Is designed for an Arduino Uno with a micro USB port. I decided just to hot glue the unit onto the mounts as it is too difficult to try and screw in.

v1.2 (Not tested) Is designed for an Arduino Uno with a micro USB port. The only changes were to clean up some of the walls to use less material.

v1.3 (Not tested) Is designed for an Arduino Uno with a standard USB port. All else is the same as v1.2.

Backstory:

Starting with the Instructables post by Eric Tsai (https://twitter.com/Eric_1100). I found inspiration with DIY home automation. Computourist (https://github.com/computourist/RFM69-MQTT-client) cleaned up the programming and added the ability to transmit to end nodes. Then I found a great forum that has simplified the build and offers a great community http://homeautomation.proboards.com/post/2053/thread

This is my attempt to contribute back to the http://homeautomation.proboards.com/ community

comments.text: Ja das Netzteil sitzt Perfekt. Beim anderen ist es das Kleine Netzteil das stimmt deshalb habe ich diesen hier noch gedruckt. Sitzt denn der Echo Dot fest bei ihnen in der Schale? Also rastet er vorne richtig ein?

author: marc186

title: Fence Knob for a Yorkcraft YC-6J Jointer

description.text: The Knob for moving the fence on my Jointer broke and I needed a replacement. The odd thing is that the knob has a 1/8th inch high tab about half way down that fits into the shaft detent. The material isn't flexible enough to allow stretching to accommodate so I solved this by using thermal insert screw holders and a pair of set screws to project into the shaft. Works great!
Added M2.5-0.45 threaded inserts into the holes to allow 14mm screws to mate with the shaft detent.
Tinkercad

The Excel generator contains macros that generates STL files for vases based on configurable parameters.
This includes:

Model height, width and depth (including ellipses)
Number of layers for the vase
Number of points in the vase cross section
Amount to rotate each layer (V2 includes continuous rotation or oscillating rotation)
Z profiles including:
Straight vases
Conical sloping in and sloping out (with varying top and base sizes)
Bulging in and Bulging out with variable amount of bulge and bulge position.

V2 includes:
Sides with waves with variable number of ½ waves and whether to start the wave inwards or outwards.

V3 includes:
Stellation of alternate points (must be even number of points) for example to change an octogon into a star.
Tetrahedral faces - to change each triangle into a tetrhedron (positive values creates outwards points on each face, negative values create inward points).
